m:agent.m:name: dk.kb.dup.metsApi software agent using data from Manuscript department at Royal Library, Copenhagen, DK.

md:note.div:
[olim kps. 20/14]
Pergament, 1 f., ca. 25 × 29 cm; Italien, 1100-1150
Aurelius Augustinus, In Evangelium Joannis tractatus, 50, 11-13 ("///at. Dixit ergo ihesus ... & se ipsum suscitavit occisum"). - De efterfølgende rubrikker på versosiden viser, at teksten indgår i en litugisk sammenhæng
Fragmentet har været brugt som omslag om Det Kongelige Biblioteks eksemplar af Lucius Fenestella, De Magistratibus Sacerdotiisque Romanorum Libellus (etc.), Basel 1538 (sign. 143:4, 67, tidligere 143, 185)
Bibl.: Katalog over Det Kongelige Biblioteks permanente Udstilling, København 1908, p. 2 no. 14 ("11. Aarh."). - E. A. Lowe, The Beneventan Script. A History of the South Italian Minuscule. Second Edition prepared and enlarged by Virginia Brown, vol. II, Hand List of Beneventan Mss., Roma 1980, p. 36 ("'Saec. XI'"). - Iter Liturgicum Italicum, a cura di Giacomo Baroffio, Padova 1999, p. 97 ("Saec. XI"). – Ifølge håndskreven note af Francis Newton (oktober 1985) kopieret "Saec. XII 1"
Erik Petersen

[olim kps. 20/14]
Parchment, 1 f., c. 25 × 29 cm; Italy, 1100-1150
Aurelius Augustinus, In Evangelium Joannis tractatus, 50, 11-13 ("///at. Dixit ergo ihesus ... & se ipsum suscitavit occisum"). – The rubrics on the verso indicate, that the text occurs in a liturgical context
The fragment was used as cover of The Royal Library’s copy of Lucius Fenestella, De Magistratibus Sacerdotiisque Romanorum Libellus (etc.), Basel 1538 (sign. 143:4, 67; olim 143, 185)
Bibl.: Katalog over Det Kongelige Biblioteks permanente Udstilling, København 1908, p. 2 no. 14 ("11. Aarh."). - E. A. Lowe, The Beneventan Script. A History of the South Italian Minuscule. Second Edition prepared and enlarged by Virginia Brown, vol. II, Hand List of Beneventan Mss., Roma 1980, p. 36 ("'Saec. XI'"). – Iter Liturgicum Italicum, a cura di Giacomo Baroffio, Padova 1999, p. 97 ("Saec. XI"). - According to a handwritten note by Francis Newton (October 1985) copied "Saec. XII 1"
Erik Petersen
